prompt: Facts: Marriage between Madhu Pamnani (Complainant/Wife) and Hanish Pamnani (Petitioner No. 1/Husband) solemnized on 05.12.2010.; Parties resided in Mumbai after marriage.; Complainant alleges dowry demands commenced soon after marriage.; Allegations include taunts for insufficient dowry and demand for Rs. 25 lacs for husband's business.; Complainant alleges physical assault by husband on 15.08.2011.; Complainant alleges husband admitted to an extra-marital affair.; Complainant alleges Smt. Jyoti Pamnani (Petitioner No. 2/Mother-in-law) supported her son and participated in harassment.; Complainant left the matrimonial home in Mumbai on 16.08.2011 and returned to her parental home in Delhi.; Husband filed a divorce petition on 09.09.2011.; Complainant lodged FIR No. 279/2013 under Sections 498A/406/34 IPC at PS Rajouri Garden, New Delhi on 16.07.2013.; Complainant alleges petitioners retained her stridhan articles, refusal to return constitutes offence under Section 406 IPC.; Petitioners (Husband and Mother-in-law) filed Crl.M.C. 4200/2013 under Section 482 CrPC before Delhi High Court seeking quashing of the FIR. | IPC: Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 406 (Punishment for criminal breach of trust), Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The FIR and accompanying documents prima facie disclose cognizable offences under Sections 498A and 406 IPC against both petitioners.", "precedents": ["Rajesh Bajaj v. State NCT of Delhi (1999) 3 SCC 259 (FIR need not be an encyclopedia, focus on whether ingredients are disclosed).", "State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal (1992 Supp (1) SCC 335 (Quashing power to be used sparingly, only if allegations do not constitute any offence).", "Sunita Kumari Kashyap v. State of Bihar (2011) 11 SCC 301 (Jurisdiction exists where consequences of cruelty ensue, e.g., wife taking shelter at parental home)."]}], "defense": [{"argument": "FIR is an abuse of the legal process, filed belatedly as a retaliatory measure against the husband's divorce petition, and lacks specific, actionable allegations against the petitioners, especially the mother-in-law.", "precedents": ["State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal (1992 Supp (1) SCC 335 (Specifically category 7: where proceeding is manifestly attended with mala fide and/or maliciously instituted with ulterior motive).", "Geeta Mehrotra v. State of U.P. (2012) 10 SCC 741 (Need for specific allegations against relatives).", "Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand (2010) 7 SCC 667 (Concern over misuse of S.498A)."]}, {"argument": "No prima facie case under S.406 IPC is made out as the list of stridhan is allegedly exaggerated, and there was willingness expressed (though disputed) to return legitimate items.", "precedents": ["Velji Raghavji Patel v. State of Maharashtra (AIR 1965 SC 1433) (Essential elements of criminal breach of trust).", "Onkar Nath Mishra v. State (NCT of Delhi) (2008) 2 SCC 561 (Distinction between civil dispute over property and criminal breach of trust).", "Insufficient data in judgment regarding specific precedent cited by defense on this point, but general principles apply."]}, {"argument": "The court should exercise its inherent powers under Section 482 CrPC to quash the FIR to prevent abuse of process and secure the ends of justice, given the nature of allegations, delay, and jurisdictional issues.", "precedents": ["R.P. Kapur v. State of Punjab (AIR 1960 SC 866) (Categories for quashing).", "State of Karnataka v. L. Muniswamy (1977) 2 SCC 699 (Inherent power to prevent abuse of process).", "Zandu Pharmaceutical Works Ltd. v. Mohd. Sharaful Haque (2005) 1 SCC 122 (Power under 482 to be exercised sparingly)."]}]}
